message.raw:
This commit contains barely tested code, however example.py does compile so it can't be too broken!

I have attempted to implement #371 or in other words:
* Users can chose the flags on which the slow clock and fast clock are output
* Users can choose not to output the slow or fast clock
* If no clocks are output, redundant loop instructions are not generated, thus allowing more value changes for the digital outputs and DDS channels

message.raw:
Added /devices submodule for stuff that you might not want imported all the time.

Currently used only for ADWin implementation, which is currently in a working state. ADWin has a funny implementation with its own digital and analog output objects since they are not so interchangable with other devices. Ramps are implemented by programming the device with ramp parameters, which it evaluates itself.

This required an 'Instruction' object capable of holding the ramp parameters rather than simply the function for the ramp.

message.raw:
Waits now have labels you give them when you request them.
Acquisitions can also specify that they are to take place during a wait.
In this case their start and end times will be interpreted with the beginning
of the wait as zero. This might mean that the acquisition ends up getting
no data at all, if the wait is short. But so be it.

This relied on chunking of data to be done in BLACS, which it still hasn't been.

Initial trigger time can be set with pseudoclock.set_initial_trigger_time(t).

start() must be called after any of these, and must be called before any output is commanded.

pseudoclocks now require a parent (the device triggering them)

message.raw:
Fixed a bug which reared its head only under very specific circumstances. If a single element ramp (I know, why the hell would you do that?) was used, and immediately followed another ramp, then there was a strange interaction between the two.

The single element ramp would modify its function evaluation time to correct for zero order hold error. The problem was, it would modify an existing mutable data structure in doing so. The previous ramp would then see this modification, and if the two ramps had different sample rates, would get an incorrect time point for its own zero order hold correction. This resulted in a grossly incorrect final point for that first ramp, as its function was evaluated at some much later time.

The fix was to ensure that the correction for zero order hold error doesn't modify the shared time arrays in the case of a one-element ramp!

This was not a contrived example, this was actually discovered whilst in use. Sure a one-element ramp is unrealistic, but it was being used to essentially 'comment out' a ramp to be a single state change. It was more convenient to leave the ramp in and make it have only one point by modifying a runmanager global than to change the code.

message.raw:
Modified import introspection such that labscript's auto initialisation can be supressed no matter where it is being imported from.
Just set a local variable labscript_auto_init = False in the scope in which you're importing labscript before you import it.
This is useful for code that needs to interact with labscript but isn't actually compiling a script right away. The two use cases for this are: runmanager's batch compiler, which compiles multiple shots in the same process one after the other, and runviewer, which I'm currently modifying to import labscript so it can tell which devices are Pseudoclocks and which aren't.
It had been telling which were Pseudoclocks by seeing that their parent device in the connection table was 'None'. However soon the parent device of a pseudoclock will be the pseudoclock triggering it, and so only the master Pseudoclock will have no parent.

The two use cases for this are: runmanager's batch compiler, which compiles multiple shots in the same process one after the other, and runviewer, which I'm currently modifying to import labscript so it can tell which devices are Pseudoclocks and which aren't.
It had been telling which were Pseudoclocks by seeing that their parent device in the connection table was 'None'. However soon the parent device of a pseudoclock will be the pseudoclock triggering it, and so only the master Pseudoclock will have no parent.

values.message:
Modified import introspection such that labscript's auto initialisation can be supressed no matter where it is being imported from.
Just set a local variable labscript_auto_init = False in the scope in which you're importing labscript before you import it.
This is useful for code that needs to interact with labscript but isn't actually compiling a script right away. The two use cases for this are: runmanager's batch compiler, which compiles multiple shots in the same process one after the other, and runviewer, which I'm currently modifying to import labscript so it can tell which devices are Pseudoclocks and which aren't.
It had been telling which were Pseudoclocks by seeing that their parent device in the connection table was 'None'. However soon the parent device of a pseudoclock will be the pseudoclock triggering it, and so only the master Pseudoclock will have no parent.

message.raw:
NI cards now require an argument MAX_name to their constructor in labscript. This is the name that will be used to tell the NI DAQMX library which card we're talking to, and does not need to match the device's name in your labscript code.

Previously the device's labscript name had to be the MAX name. But now we're making this in line with the rest of labscript, where a device's name and directions for communicating it are stored separately.

message.raw:
a (hopefully temporary) fix for bug #610.
This is in the h5_lock module, which is where I was hacking things onto h5py anyway. I've disabled the actual h5_locking for the moment, until I make a few changes to pythonlib to accomodate it, such as BLACS worker processes not holding the file open for minutes at a time while they program a device (I'm looking at you, novatech) when they could easily close the file prior to programming.

Added imports everywhere needed throughout pythonlib

message.raw:
Made a fix where the RFblaster binary data could not we written to the h5 file in h5py 2.1.0.  This was because, according to the exception, 'variable length strings cannot contain embedded nulls'. h5py didn't used to support variable length strings as an array datatype, so our binary data (which presumably contains embedded nulls) was converted to numpy fixes length strings.

Since we don't have an array, and thus don't care if the array element strings have the same lengths or not, the fix was simply to convert to numpy.string_, which is what the data used to be stored as in h5py < 2.1.0.

message.raw:
Added a no_warnings context manager. When used, all warnings are supressed. Use it like this:

with no_warnings:
    function_that_would_normally_generate_a_warning()

This could be useful for supressing warnings when it is known that they do not pose a problem, allowing unexpected warnings to not be drowned out in the noise.

'mild' warnings (everything but value-at-certain-time-is-being-overwritten warnings) are still supressed by default, they can be re-enabled by setting config.supress_mild_warnings to False, and then supressed selectively with the context manager if desired.

message.raw:
Changes to how labscript handles initialisation and cleanup.
Since runmanager runs labscripts repeatedly, and labscript does initialisation at import time, we've previously been handling this by reloading labscript every run.
This has caused some nasty interaction with ModuleWatcher which I don't quite understand.
Since this was pretty bad practise anyway, labscript now has explicit init and cleanup functions. Usage is still identical in that initialisation still happens at import time, however there is now the option to supress auto-initialisation by setting labscript_auto_init = False in your __main__ module. runmanager's batch_compiler does this and then calls labscript.labscript_init(h5_file, labscript_file) and labscript.labscript_cleanup() explicitly for every shot it compiles, rather than munging sys.argv and simulating a fresh import.

This seems like a much cleaner solution. A quick test will reveal if this fixes #600 (The ModuleWatcher crash)

message.raw:
Fixed a bug where the "WARNING" message regarding the overwriting of a value would display the new value in the specified units, but the old value in base units.

This would give the false impression that values were being overwritten and changed to a new value, even when the values were identical.

All values are now displayed in base units, and the error message has been updated to reflect this.

message.raw:
Fixed some bugs with the hardware triggering of a secondary PulseBlaster.

This mainly revolves around the staticDDS which inserts an instruction at t=0 to set it's output. However, due to the finite triggering time of the pulseblaster, even if you were to trigger it at t=0, no instructions can be issued on that device (or it's children) until t>=250ns. This causes problems when a Novatech is attached to a secondary pulseblaster.

The solution is to not store the StaticDDS (StaticAnalogQuantity) value in an instruction, but rather as a simple attribute of the class!

message.raw:
Added the ability to trigger pulseblasters, either via a software trigger or a hardware trigger (note that the software trigger is not implemented in BLACS yet).

NOTE: ALL PULSBLASTERS MUST BE TRIGGERED USING THIS NEW CODE

Example:
# Here we 'software' trigger a pulseblaster at t=0.
# Note this doesn't actually do anything yet, but is needed!
t=0
pulseblaster_0.trigger(t,'software')
# Here we trigger a pulseblaster using a digital channel called pb_1_trigger
# Note that if you trigger at t=0, you must have left the trigger HIGH
# at the end of the last experiment, or else you will leave your
# pulseblaster in a state that continually triggers itself
t+=7
pulseblaster_1.trigger(t,pb_1_trigger)

Now that you have triggered pulseblaster_1 at t=7s, times given to channels on this pulseblaster should be referenced to t=0 (the start of the entire experiment). So ao.constant(8,3,'A') will set the channel ao to 3A 1s after triggering the pulseblaster at t=7s

SIMPLE IMPLEMENTATION: If you wish to edit your code as little as possible, just software trigger pulseblaster0, and hardware trigger the other pulseblasters using the above syntax at t=0

Furthermore, to facilitate this feature, the ramping functions in functions.py now return a lambda function which takes t-t0 as a parameter, where t0 is the start time of the ramp, and t is the time at which you wish to evaluate the function. This will not affect using the ramp functions of the AnalogQuantity, but will affect your code if you directly call functions.ramp etc.

TODO: Take into account the minor delay between sending the trigger signal, and triggering the Pulseblaster (on the order of 10s of nanoseconds)

message.raw:
Function ramps now take relative times rather than absolute. That is, the lambdas returned by function in functions.py are evaluated at timepoints measured from the beginning of the ramp, rather than from the beginning of the experiment.

This does not affect existing labscripts, but means that new functions must be implemented accordingly.

This change was made to facilitate delayed triggering of devices -- where a device is only triggered to begin its run after t = 0. Having the lambdas take times relative to the start time of their corresponding ramps makes it easier to offset these ramps later to match the delayed trigger time.

message.raw:
Fixed a bug where importing an entire module from labscript could try and save the contents of the __init__ file twice in the HDF5 file. Now labscript only saves import contents if it isn't already saved in the HDF5 file.

Also added is a type cnversion of globals from numpy._bool to bool, and the exp_ramp and exp_t_ramp functions have been modified to use truncation if "trunc is not False". This ensures that you can successfully truncate at trunc=0, which previously evaluated as False due to the if statement being "if trunc:"

message.raw: Changed some datatypes of RFblaster tables, such that bigger integers are allowed, to allow for longer wait times. The RFblaster is capable of quite long wait times by looping wait instructions, so it's pointless to limit the wait time to 2**31 * 13.33ns prior to those loops being constructed.

message.raw:
Some RFBlaster related changes.

Labscript pseudoclocks now store all timespoints at 64 bit floats. This helps the RFblaster's preprocessor wrap repetitive timesteps into loops better. The rounding error in 32 bit floats was growing larger than the RFblaster's quantisation.

Also, labscript now uses RFJuice's Cython compiler. It is much faster. To get it, pull + update your mercurual working copy of rfjuice, go into the cython folder, and compile the extension by running:

python setup.py build_ext --inplace

message.raw:
Added a check for if the device name already exists in the python namespace or if it is a python keyword.

Prevents problems when generic names like "test" are used as device names which conflicts with the numpy class test. Since the labscript device is placed in __builtins__, the numpy variable takes preference in some scopes (such as the __main__ block).

message.raw:
refs #534

The parameters for the camera object instantiation in labscript now include:
serial_number, SDK and effective_pixel_size and these are stored as attributes to each camera in the devices group.

*These parameters are required. See example.py for an example!*

SDK should be specified as a string
serial_number can be a hexadecimal number (0x1E) or a hexadecimal string (either "0x1E" or just "1E"). It is stored as a uint64 in the h5 file.
effective_pixel_size should be specified in units of meters as a single number [eg: 4.6e-6]. (we assume square pixels always, can add non square capability on request)

*These parameters are required. See example.py for an example!*

SDK should be specified as a string
serial_number can be a hexadecimal number (0x1E) or a hexadecimal string (either "0x1E" or just "1E"). It is stored as a uint64 in the h5 file.
effective_pixel_size should be specified in units of meters as a single number [eg: 4.6e-6]. (we assume square pixels always, can add non square capability on request)

message.raw:
You can now turn on and off warnings of the 'has no instructions' and 'has no instructions at t=0' kind by doing:

import labscript
labscript.config.suppress_mild_warnings = False # is True by default

or if you import *, you can just set config.suppress_mild_warnings. config is just a container class that I plan on using for this sort of stuff.

(This change fixes #519)

message.raw:
Some refactoring of labscript.
Labscript now only opens the hdf5 file when it needs it, rather than just having it open the whole time whilst the user's code is running. The file is only open in a context manager, which means that if an exception is raised, the file will be closed.
Previously exceptions would be raised and the files would only close upon the process exiting. This was all well and good, since most labscript errors explicity called sys.exit(), and the process would end, and the files would close. However, now that labscripts are being compiled in a long-running process by runmanager, the process does not end. So we need to make sure those files get closed, otherwise we can't delete failed compilations without closing runmanager.
I've also replaced all labscript errors with 'raise LabscriptError(message)' instead of 'sys.stderr.write(message); sys.exit(1)'. This provides a traceback so that users can see where things went wrong, and it also allows for easier future modification by catching the LabscriptError exception class instead of a giant find and replace (there were 58).
I've also disabled 'minor' warnings by default, where an output's value isn't defined at t=0 (or ever). Now the only warnings you get are when you set an output to two values at the same time. These are actually pretty important, so hopefully the decrease in visual pollution will make people read them and make mistakes in their experiments less often.
This change also makes it a bit easier to refactor labscript further, since there are now no global varaibles.

Some refactoring of labscript.
Labscript now only opens the hdf5 file when it needs it, rather than just having it open the whole time whilst the user's code is running. The file is only open in a context manager, which means that if an exception is raised, the file will be closed.
Previously exceptions would be raised and the files would only close upon the process exiting. This was all well and good, since most labscript errors explicity called sys.exit(), and the process would end, and the files would close. However, now that labscripts are being compiled in a long-running process by runmanager, the process does not end. So we need to make sure those files get closed, otherwise we can't delete failed compilations without closing runmanager.
I've also replaced all labscript errors with 'raise LabscriptError(message)' instead of 'sys.stderr.write(message); sys.exit(1)'. This provides a traceback so that users can see where things went wrong, and it also allows for easier future modification by catching the LabscriptError exception class instead of a giant find and replace (there were 58).
I've also disabled 'minor' warnings by default, where an output's value isn't defined at t=0 (or ever). Now the only warnings you get are when you set an output to two values at the same time. These are actually pretty important, so hopefully the decrease in visual pollution will make people read them and make mistakes in their experiments less often.
This change also makes it a bit easier to refactor labscript further, since there are now no global varaibles.

message.raw:
the exp_ramp function of AnalogQuantity did not return duration.

This bug will only have affected the spinorlab if they were calling:
t += channel.exp_ramp(....)
which I don't think they were (I don't think it was responsible for bug #511 as the ramp functions were not in use as the channels were not on the fast clock)

The bug was already fixed in the working copy of the dual_species lab, but not committed due to the function being modified further by Shaun.

The bug was fixed in the working copy of the spinor lab on Friday morning, but not committed.

It is now committed!
